fields.label_text:
Dish
Made at Langau, Canton Berne, Switzerland dated 1782
Lead-glazed earthenware with 'sgraffito' decoration

1019-1905

Dish, made at Langnau, Switzerland, dated 1782
1019-1905

fields.descriptive_line: Red earthenware covered with a white slip and with incised decoration picked out in red slip, green, yellow and brown under a yellowish clear glaze. Swiss (Langnau), dated 1782.
fields.physical_description:
Dark red earthenware, covered on the upper side with a white slip, with sgraffiato decoration picked out in red slip, green, yellow and manganese-purple coloured glazes under a yellowish glaze; marbled glazing on the underside. There is an inscription around the rim.
Circular with sunken centre in which is a parrot between two floral sprays. Round the rim within the inscription are sprays springing from medallions (or pomegranates) alternating with rosettes.
fields.materials_techniques: Lead-glazed earthenware covered with slip, with incised decoration and painted in colours

fields.location: Ceramics Study Galleries, Asia & Europe, room 137, case J2, shelf 2
fields.marks: Elsbeth Wolter. Wir laben und wussen nicht wie lang. Wir sterben und wussen nicht wann, wir faren und wussen nicht wohin, mich verwundres dass ich noch frolich bin.  We live and know not how long, we die and know not when, we journey and know not whither, 'tis a wonder to me that still I am cheerful.

fields.location: Ceramics Study Galleries, Asia & Europe, room 137

fields.name: Ceramics Study Galleries, Asia & Europe, room 137

fields.public_access_description:
Langnau is located in the Emmental region, Canton Berne, in Switzerland. Lead-glazed ceramic production here began probably in the 17th century and carried on into the 19th century. More recently, there has been a resurgence of interest in traditional lead-glazed incised slipware in the region and new potteries have emerged.

Dishes, or bowls, of a similar size and decoration are found in collections in Switzerland and in Germany. From about 1725 to 1760, the central imagery is primarily floral. After this and until the early years of the 19th century, the central imagery consists of fish, birds and human forms. They exhibit a variety of inscriptions which, although, specific to the person who commissioned the bowl, are not related to the imagery depicted. It has been assumed in the past that if the bowl had, for example, a central image of a fish, it was meant to be used as a dish for cooked fish, and other such image/function connections.  It is now believed that these dishes were used for a variety of food items. The fine decoration suggests that they were used on special occasions rather than for daily use.

The similarities between this dish and one now in the Historisches Museum in Bern are striking. The wide border design of alternating rosettes, 'pomegranates' and leaf forms is the same and the construction of the letters in the inscription is very similiar. The dish in Bern bears the initials 'S.C.' and it is very likely that S.C. is also responsible for the V&A dish.
fields.bibliography:
Hermann Buchs, Vom Heimberger Geschirr zur Thuner Majolika. Thun, 1988
Ethnologisches Seminar der Universität Basel (Ed.), Berner Töpferei. Mensch und Handwerk. St. Gallen, 1983
Katrin Roth-Rubi, Chacheli us em Bode. Der Kellerfund im Haus 315 in Nidfluh, Därstetten. Ein Händlerdepot. Wimmis, 2000
Robert L. Wyss, Berner Bauernkeramik (Berner Heimatbücher). Bern, 1966 (pl.X) Illustrating a dish with the same rim decoration, similiar inscription style and the same diameter. Dated 1784 and signed 'S.C.'. In the Historisches Museum in Bern.
Hermann Jedding, Volkstumliche Keramik aus Deutschsprachigen Landern, Museum fur Kunst und Gewerbe, Hamburg, 1976 fig. 69 similar decoration on the border and in the script. This has a human figure incised in the centre.
Adriano Boschetti-Maradi, Gefasskeramik und Hafnerei in der Fruhen Neuzeit im Kanton Bern, Verlag Bernisches Historisches Museum, Bern, 2006
Emil, Aeschlimann, Alt Langnau-Topferei, Bern, 1928 See for a study of the families named and types of inscription.
Gastronomy and Old Tableware in Switzerland, Swiss National Tourist Office, Zurich, 1956
fields.history_note:
Langnau is in Canton Berne.
Bought along with 1020-1905 for £4 from Mons. Emile Calame (5 rue du Grand-Chene, Lausanne).
The similarities between this dish and the one in Bern (see Wyss in References) are striking. The wide border design of alternating floral and leaf forms is the same. The construction of the letters is almost precise. The dish in Bern bears the initials 'S.C.' and it is very likely that S.C. is also responsible for the V&A dish.

Dishes, or bowls, of a similar size and decoration are found in collections in Switzerland and in Germany. From about 1725 to 1760, the central imagery is primarily floral. After this and until the early years of the 19th century, the central imagery consists of fish, birds and human forms. They exhibit a variety of inscriptions which, although, specific to the person who commissioned the bowl, are not related to the imagery depicted. It has been assumed in the past that if the bowl had, for example, a central image of a fish, it was meant to be used as a dish for cooked fish, and other such image/function connections.  It is now believed that these dishes were used for a variety of food items. The fine decoration suggests that they were used on special occasions rather than for daily use.
